commander.name: Generalleutnant Erwin Rommel
commander.notes: Promoted to Generalfeldmarschall on 22 June 1942. Commanded DAK Feb-Sept 1941 until formation of Panzergruppe Afrika. Most famous German commander in North Africa.

chief_of_staff.name: Oberstleutnant Alfred Gause
chief_of_staff.notes: Continued as chief of staff through Panzergruppe Afrika

command.headquarters_location: Mobile HQ, Cyrenaica (Libya) - typically near forward divisions
command.parent_command: OKW direct control (March-August 1941), then Panzergruppe Afrika (September 1941)

Panzer II Ausf C.notes: Reconnaissance tanks (32 from 15. Pz, 20 from 5. l.D)

Opel Blitz 3-ton.notes: Standard Wehrmacht truck (650 from 15. Pz, 520 from 5. l.D)

Mercedes-Benz L3000.notes: Heavy transport (420 from 15. Pz, 380 from 5. l.D)

Büssing-NAG.notes: Artillery tractor (220 from 15. Pz, 240 from 5. l.D)

Krupp L2H143.notes: Light cargo (160 from 15. Pz, 180 from 5. l.D)

Horch Kfz.15.notes: Staff cars (100 from 5. l.D, 5 corps HQ)

Fuel tankers.notes: 135 from 15. Pz, 18 from 5. l.D, 12 corps pool

Water tankers.notes: 110 from 15. Pz, 15 corps pool, 10 from various

Workshop vehicles.notes: 85 from 15. Pz, 22 from 5. l.D, 13 corps pool

Ambulances.notes: 65 from 15. Pz, 13 from 5. l.D, 10 corps medical

Staff cars.notes: 30 from 15. Pz (also listed in trucks category)

5cm PaK 38.notes: Primary AT gun (24 from 15. Pz, 18 from 5. l.D)

3.7cm PaK 35/36.notes: Light AT gun, being phased out (18 from 15. Pz, 9 from 5. l.D)

8.8cm FlaK 18/36.notes: Dual-purpose AA/AT (12 from 15. Pz, 8 from 5. l.D). Highly effective in anti-tank role

2cm FlaK 38.notes: Improved light AA (8 from 15. Pz, 24 from 5. l.D)

fighters.note: Luftwaffe support provided at theater level by Fliegerführer Afrika (not organic to DAK)

reconnaissance.note: Fieseler Fi 156 Storch aircraft used for liaison by Rommel, not counted in corps TO&E

supply_logistics.supply_status: Critical - Extended supply lines from Tripoli (800-1000+ km) via single coastal road (Via Balbia). British naval interdiction (Malta-based RAF/RN) destroys 30-40% of Axis convoys. Fuel reserves 7-8 days, ammunition 10-12 days, water 10-15L/man/day (critical desert constraint), food 12-14 days. Capture of British supply dumps essential for sustained operations (Operation Brevity/Battleaxe yielded fuel, rations). Supply base: Tripoli port (sole Axis lifeline). Forward supply dumps at Benghazi (when controlled) and Bardia.

weather_environment.terrain_type: Coastal desert (Cyrenaica/Marmarica) - sand, gravel, rocky escarpments, wadis, minimal vegetation, no water sources. Operational area: Cyrenaica coast (Tripoli-Tobruk-Egyptian border)

subordinate_units.composition: Panzer-Regiment 8, Schützen-Regimenter 104/115, Kradschützen-Bataillon 15, Artillerie-Regiment 33, support units
subordinate_units.equipment_summary: 155 tanks (109 medium, 46 light), 72 field artillery, 42 AT guns, 2850 vehicles

subordinate_units.composition: Panzer-Regiment 5, Infanterie-Regiment (mot.) z.b.V. 200, MG-Bataillone 2/8, Aufklärungs-Abteilung 3, Artillerie-Regiment 75 (I. only), support units
subordinate_units.equipment_summary: 85 tanks (55 medium, 30 light), 36 field artillery, 27 AT guns, 2100 vehicles
Radio trucks, telephone equipment, telegraph, motorcycles
subordinate_units.notes: Only organic corps troop unit documented in Tessin Band 14. Essential for coordination of mobile operations.

tactical_doctrine.role: First German armored corps deployed to North Africa. Mobile armored exploitation force for offensive operations, breakthrough warfare, rapid maneuver in desert terrain. Combined arms coordination at corps level between panzer divisions, motorized infantry, and supporting arms.
special_capabilities: Rapid exploitation of breakthroughs via two panzer divisions
Mobile defensive operations using 8.8cm FlaK in AT role
Combined arms coordination (tanks, motorized infantry, artillery, AT, AA)
Battlefield improvisation (capture and use of British supplies)
tactical_innovations: Revolutionary use of 8.8cm FlaK guns in anti-tank role (devastating vs British cruiser/infantry tanks)
Mobile AT gun screens (PaK 38, 8.8cm FlaK) to lure British armor into kill zones
Rapid desert exploitation using sun compass/dead reckoning navigation
Aggressive use of reconnaissance to find flanks
Capture and immediate use of British fuel/supply dumps
Concentration of armor at decisive points (Schwerpunkt doctrine)
Mobile workshops for rapid battlefield repairs
known_issues: Insufficient tank numbers vs British armored forces (240 tanks vs British 200+ Matilda/Crusader/Cruiser tanks)
Extended supply lines (800-1000+ km from Tripoli) via single coastal road
British naval/air interdiction destroys 30-40% of Axis supply convoys
Desert conditions: extreme heat, sand (vehicle breakdowns), water scarcity (10-15L/man/day essential)
3.7cm PaK 35/36 inadequate against Matilda II infantry tanks (78mm frontal armor)
Limited spare parts (vehicles/tanks cannibalized for parts)
Vulnerability of soft-skinned vehicles to British air attacks
Chronic fuel shortages (7-8 days reserves, limits operational tempo)
Italian forces require German stiffening (morale/training issues)
No organic air support (dependent on Fliegerführer Afrika at theater level)
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Tropical uniforms (khaki), sand filters on all vehicles, desert tires, increased water capacity (tankers), sun compass/dead reckoning navigation, vehicle recovery emphasis (limited replacements), water discipline (10-15L/man/day), capture of British supply dumps essential, mobile workshops for field repairs, aggressive reconnaissance (water sources, supply dumps, enemy positions)

scenario_suitability: Operation Battleaxe (June 15-17, 1941) - British offensive, German defensive victory
Desert patrol actions and reconnaissance battles
Anti-tank ambush scenarios (8.8cm FlaK vs British armor)
special_rules: Rommel leadership bonus: +1 to all DAK units within 5km of Rommel's HQ
8.8cm FlaK guns may fire in AT role (exceptional vs all British armor)
Superior combined arms coordination: +1 to coordination checks
Desert warfare experience: +1 to navigation/survival checks
Extended supply lines penalty: -1 to sustained operations after 5 days without resupply
Panzer III 50mm gun effective against British cruiser tanks (Crusader, A10, A13)
British Matilda II infantry tanks immune to 3.7cm PaK (require 5cm PaK or 8.8cm FlaK)
Capture British supply dumps: +2 days fuel/ammunition if British supply dump overrun
historical_engagements: Operation Sonnenblume (24 March - 11 April 1941) - Rommel's first offensive, drove British from Cyrenaica
First Battle of Sollum (14 April 1941) - Captured Sollum/Halfaya Pass
First Siege of Tobruk begins (11 April 1941) - Failed to capture, siege begins
Operation Brevity (15-17 May 1941) - British counteroffensive, DAK defensive victory
Operation Skorpion (15-16 May 1941) - DAK counterattack recaptures Halfaya Pass
Operation Battleaxe (15-17 June 1941) - Major British offensive, decisive DAK defensive victory (96 British tanks destroyed vs 12 German)
Siege of Tobruk operations (April-November 1941) - Continuous investment, failed assaults

source: Tessin Band 14 - Deutsches Afrikakorps organizational structure (Tier 1, 95% confidence)
Nafziger Collection - German OOB North Africa 1941 (Tier 1, 83% confidence)
The Rommel Papers - Primary source, Rommel's personal letters/diary Q2 1941 (Tier 1, 90% confidence)
Osprey Men-at-Arms #53: Rommel's Desert Army (Tier 2, 82% confidence)
Feldgrau.com - DAK unit history, commanders, subordinate units (Tier 2, 80% confidence)
Lexikon der Wehrmacht - DAK entry with organizational details (Tier 2, 80% confidence)
Panzerworld - Tank strength data for DAK 1941 (Tier 2, 78% confidence)
Cross-referenced: Rommel commanding (14 Feb 1941) - multiple sources (Keilig, Mitcham, Rommel Papers)
Cross-referenced: Crüwell replaced Rommel on 1 Sept 1941 (outside Q2)
Cross-referenced: Chief of Staff Alfred Gause - Rommel Papers, Mitcham
Cross-referenced: Subordinate divisions (15. Pz, 5. l.D) - all sources agree
Aggregated: Equipment totals from canonical division TO&E files (15. Pz + 5. l.D)
Calculated: Corps troops personnel (345) from Pz.Korps-Nachr.Abt. 475
Calculated: Supply/logistics from Q2 1941 historical operations (Brevity, Battleaxe)
Schema v3.1.0: supply_logistics and weather_environment sections complete
validation.confidence_tier: Excellent - Tier 1 sources (Tessin, Nafziger, Rommel Papers) with division aggregation
known_gaps: Corps troops limited to Pz.Korps-Nachr.Abt. 475 only (Tessin lists no other organic corps units)
Additional Luftwaffe Flak units attached to DAK but not organic (e.g., Flak-Regiment 33)
Italian units under DAK operational control not included (separate Italian TO&E)
Exact corps HQ personnel breakdown estimated (65 officers, 95 NCOs, 185 enlisted)
Support vehicle distribution between divisions/corps pool estimated
Equipment operational readiness percentages averaged from divisional data
Individual company commanders for Pz.Korps-Nachr.Abt. 475 unknown
validation.data_quality_assessment: EXCELLENT - Corps-level TO&E aggregated from canonical division files (15. Panzer-Division, 5. leichte Division) plus corps troops (Pz.Korps-Nachr.Abt. 475) from Tessin Band 14. Commander Rommel and Chief of Staff Gause confirmed from multiple Tier 1 sources. Tank totals (240) and personnel (25,695) calculated from division aggregation. Supply situation documented from Rommel Papers Q2 1941 entries (Operation Brevity/Battleaxe period). Weather/terrain data from North Africa Q2 1941 historical records. Excellent foundation for wargaming scenarios (Operation Battleaxe primary).
research_notes: DAK formed 16 Feb 1941 as 'Befehlshaber der deutschen Truppen in Libyen', renamed 21 Feb 1941
Rommel commanding 14 Feb 1941 - 1 Sept 1941 (replaced by Crüwell when Panzergruppe Afrika formed)
Q2 1941 subordinate divisions: 15. Panzer-Division, 5. leichte Division (redesignated 21. Pz 1 Aug)
Corps troops: Only Pz.Korps-Nachr.Abt. 475 documented in Tessin (signals battalion)
Aggregate strength: 25,695 personnel (12,850 from 15. Pz + 12,500 from 5. l.D + 345 corps)
Aggregate tanks: 240 (155 from 15. Pz + 85 from 5. l.D), 91.7% operational
Operation Battleaxe (15-17 June 1941): DAK's greatest Q2 1941 defensive victory, 96 British tanks destroyed vs 12 German
Supply crisis Q2 1941: British naval interdiction destroys 30-40% of convoys, Rommel writes 'fuel situation critical'
8.8cm FlaK revolutionized desert warfare: Used in AT role, devastating vs British Matilda/Crusader tanks
Rommel Papers document supply issues, heat (107°F recorded), tank operations, British attacks
Q2 1941 operations: Sonnenblume (Feb-Apr), Tobruk siege begins (11 Apr), Brevity (15-17 May), Battleaxe (15-17 Jun)
